questions.text: A patient with leprosy presented with the deformity as shown below. Which nerve injury causes the given condition ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows extension at the metacarpophalangeal joint and flexion at interphalangeal joints of the ring and little finger, caused by ulnar nerve injury. It produces a claw hand (main en griffe). Leprosy can affect peripheral nerves and lead to their associated conditions.

In ulnar nerve palsy, only the medial two fingers develop clawing, while in a combined median and ulnar nerve palsy, all four fingers develop clawing. 

The ulnar nerve supplies the medial two lumbricals in the hand. The lumbricals have a combined action on metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joint flexion and interphalangeal (IP) joint extension (glass holding posture). In ulnar nerve injury, since the medial lumbricals are not functional, the forearm muscles are unopposed. Hence, there is hyperextension at MCP joints and flexion at IP joints. This causes claw hand deformity. There is also numbness of the ulnar one and a half fingers. 

Elbow fractures or dislocations lead to high lesions of the ulnar nerve. Here, the hand is not markedly deformed because the ulnar half of the flexor digitorum profundus is paralyzed and the fingers, therefore, appear less clawed. This is called the high ulnar paradox.

The following tests are done to test the integrity of the ulnar nerve:

  • Egawa's test - In a positive test, due to the weakness of the dorsal interossei, side-to-side movements of the middle finger is weak.
  • Book test or Froment's sign - The patient is asked to hold a book forcefully while the doctor tries to pull it. In a positive test, due to weakness of adductor pollicis muscle, adduction of thumb is lost. The patient tries to hold the book by using flexor pollicis longus muscle. This produces flexion at the inter-phalangeal joint while holding the book.
  • Card test - In the case of weak palmar interossei, it is easy for the examiner to pull out the card when held between the fingers. This is due to the loss of adduction by palmar interossei muscles.

 

 

Other options

Option B - In radial nerve palsy, the patient presents with 'wrist drop' in case of paralyzed wrist extensors, and 'finger drop' when extensor digitorum is paralyzed. When there is compression in the axilla, radial nerve palsy is called Saturday night palsy. There is paralysis of the triceps, and weakness of the wrist and hand. In high lesions, there is sensory loss on the dorsum of the hand over the anatomical stuff box. 

Option C - In median nerve injury, paralysis of opponens pollicis muscle leads to 'ape thumb' deformity. In forearm or elbow injuries, there is paralysis of long flexors of the thumb, index, and middle fingers, radial wrist flexors, and forearm pronators. This leads to the characteristic 'pointing index finger'. There is sensory loss over three and a half digits on the radial side. 

Option D -Posterior interosseous nerve injury, is seen in posterior interosseous syndrome. The wrist is in radial deviation and there is loss of metacarpophalangeal joint extension. However, wrist extension is preserved.

questions.text: A man was rushed to the casualty after getting stabbed in the back with a knife. On MRI, a complete transection of one side of the spinal cord is suspected. Which of the following is likely to be seen in this patient?

choices.text: Pain and temperature loss on the opposite side
Fine touch lost on the opposite side
Pain and temperature lost on the same side
Only pain lost on the same side

questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Brown-Sequard syndrome. It is characterized by loss of pain and temperature on the opposite side.

Hemisection of the spinal cord causes damage to ascending sensory (dorsal column pathway, ventrolateral spinothalamic tract) and descending motor (corticospinal tract) pathways, which is called the Brown-Séquard syndrome.

The lesion to fasciculus gracilus or fasciculus cuneatus leads to ipsilateral loss of discriminative touch, vibration, and proprioception below the level of the lesion.

The loss of the spinothalamic tract leads to contra­lateral loss of pain and temperature sensation beginning one or two segments below the lesion.

Damage to the cor­ticospinal tract produces weakness and spasticity in certain muscle groups on the same side of the body.

Related Pearl: Brown Sequard syndrome (Hemisection of spinal cord)

questions.text: A patient is brought with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss, and poor wound healing. Which mineral deficiency is responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
The symptoms and clinical findings suggest a probable diagnosis of acrodermatitis enteropathica which is due to the deficiency of zinc.

It is an autosomal recessive disease due to a defect in zinc-absorbing transmembrane protein.

The symptoms are:

  • Growth retardation
  • Diarrhea
  • Alopecia
  • Rash involving the extremities, face, and perineum - rash is characterized by vesicular and pustular crusting with scaling and erythema
  • Gonadal atrophy
  • Muscle wasting
  • Impaired wound healing

questions.text: A 24-year old male patient presents with anemia. His father and paternal aunt had a similar illness that was treated successfully by splenectomy. His peripheral blood smear is similar to that shown in the illustration below. Which of the following additional abnormalities is expected?
questions.solution:
The above image showing spherocytes present on the peripheral blood smear and, along with the history, strongly suggest a diagnosis of hereditary spherocytosis (HS). The presence of Howell-Jolly bodies is an additional abnormality which can be expected here.

It is an autosomal dominant inheritance disorder. It is due to defective ankyrin, band 3, spectrin, or band 4.2 proteins causing a defect in the red cell membrane. This causes red cells to shed membrane vesicles and transform into spherocytes. The non-deformable spherocytes get trapped in the splenic cords and are phagocytosed by macrophages.

  • Most common mode of inheritance of HS: Autosomal dominant
  • Most common gene mutation in autosomal dominant HS: Ankyrin > Band 3

Clinical presentation:

The patients usually present with anemia, gall stones, splenomegaly, and jaundice but the age of presentation varies with the severity of the disease. They might also have a family history.

Aplastic crisis might occur where red cell production comes to a halt due to parvovirus infection. This lasts for 1 to 2 weeks which is usually the time required for the immune system to clear the virus. Blood transfusions may be needed during this period.

Morphology :

  • The most common finding is spherocytosis, which presents as small, dark-staining (hyperchromic) red cells without the central zone of pallor but this is not specific to HS. 
  • Features seen in HS are :
    • Reticulocytosis- increased reticulocyte count
    • Howell-Jolly bodies- dense basophilic nuclear remnants in the RBCs.
    • Marrow erythroid hyperplasia
    • Hemosiderosis
  • Splenomegaly as a result of congested Billroth cords and increased phagocytes.

Diagnosis:

Based on family history, peripheral smear findings, and laboratory investigations an adequate diagnosis is made. Increased osmotic fragility is seen in majority of the cases. They also show an increased MCHC (mean corpuscular hemoglobin concentration) due to cellular dehydration.

Note- Heinz bodies: Undeterred oxidation of hemoglobin in the RBCs leads to the formation of denatured precipitates known as Heinz bodies. These bodies damage the RBC membrane. When these RBCs pass through the splenic cords, macrophages pluck out these precipitates, giving them the characteristic appearance of bite cells. They are seen in cases of chemical poisoning, drug toxicity, glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency, or the presence of unstable hemoglobin (e.g. hemoglobin Köln)

Below image shows Heinz bodies and bite cells.

questions.text: A farmer presents with a swollen foot and multiple sinuses as shown in the below image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis here is Mycetoma which is caused by Eumycetoma.

Mycetoma:-

  • Mycetoma is a chronic, granulomatous infection of the skin, subcutaneous tissues, fascia and bone, which most often affects the foot or the hand. It is, therefore, commonly known as Maduramycosis or Madura foot. Mycetoma occurs worldwide.
  • Etiology:  It can be divided into three types, eumycetomas, actinomycetomas and botryomycosis.

Pathogenesis:-

  • Triad of symptoms: Infection follows traumatic inoculation of the organism into the subcutaneous tissue and results in tumefactions, deformities and draining sinuses discharging fungal colonies called grains or granules (triad of symptoms). 
  • Subcutaneous tissues of the feet, lower extremities, hands, and exposed areas are most often involved.

Laboratory Diagnosis

  • A. Direct Examination: The presence of grains in pus collected from draining sinuses or in biopsy material is diagnostic.
  • B. Culture Samples should also be cultured, at both 25–30°C and 37°C, on brain-heart infusion agar or blood agar for actinomycetes and on Sabouraud agar (without cycloheximide) for fungi.

Treatment:-

The management of eumycetoma is difficult, involving surgical debridement or excision and chemotherapy. Actinomycetoma responds well to rifampicin in combination with sulfonamides or cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A  public witness of the incident is asked to attend the court and record his evidence. Which type of evidence is provided by the witness to the court?
questions.solution:
The evidence provided by a public witness of the incident to the court is oral evidence.

Oral evidence is given by a person who has personal knowledge of the facts associated with a particular incident. It is the evidence given by an eyewitness. The oral evidence should be direct whenever possible according to Section 60 of the Indian Evidence Act(IEA). It includes all the statements made by the witness in relation to the inquiry which is permitted by the court. 

Other options: 

Option B: Hearsay evidence is a type of evidence given by a person who has no personal knowledge of the facts in relation to the incident but only repeats what he heard others saying. 

Option C: Subpnea is also known as summons. It is an authoritative call to appear in court. It is a document compelling the attendance of a witness in a Court of law under penalty, on a particular day, time, and place, for the purpose of giving evidence. It is issued by the Court. Section 61 to 69 of CrPc deals with the summons. 

Option D: Circumstantial evidence is also known as indirect evidence. It is not the direct testimony of an eye witness but has a bearing upon the fact of the other and subsidiary facts which are relied upon as consistent. This type of evidence needs the Court of Law to make reasonable inferences based on the information presented.

questions.text: A school-going child presents with a history of recurrent upper respiratory tract infections, mouth breathing, and impaired hearing. On examination, a high arched palate is noted. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture is suggestive of adenoid hypertrophy. The best line of management is adenoidectomy with grommet insertion.

Indications of adenoidectomy:

  • Adenoid hypertrophy causing snoring, mouth breathing, sleep apnoea syndrome, or speech abnormalities, i.e. (rhinolalia clausa)
  • Recurrent rhinosinusitis
  • Chronic otitis media with effusion associated with adenoid hyperplasia
  • Recurrent ear discharge in benign CSOM associated with adenoiditis/adenoid hyperplasia
  • Dental malocclusion. Adenoidectomy does not correct dental abnormalities but will prevent their recurrence after orthodontic treatment

questions.text: A patient presents with a sudden painless loss of vision in his right eye. On fundus examination, the following finding was seen. Which among the following conditions is likely?
questions.solution:
The image shows a splashed tomato appearance which is characteristic of central retinal vein occlusion (CRVO). 

CRVO refers to sudden or acute occlusion of the central retinal vein. It presents with a sudden loss of vision. On examination, RAPD (relative afferent pupillary defect) is present.

Funduscopy shows engorged and tortuous retinal veins, massive retinal hemorrhages with splashed tomato appearance, and cotton wool spots. The disc is edematous and hyperemic. Changes that occur later include neovascularization at the disc or periphery with pigmentary changes at the macula.

Complications:

  • Rubeosis iridis or neovascularization of the iris
  • Neovascular glaucoma (NVG) or 100 day glaucoma
  • Vitreous hemorrhage

100-day glaucoma is a type of neovascular glaucoma (NVG) and is so-called because it typically develops 3 months after the episode of CRVO.

Other options:

Option A- The funduscopy findings in central retinal artery occlusion include pale retina, thread-like arteries, a cherry-red spot in the macula, and cattle trucking (segmentation of blood in the retinal veins). It is shown below.

Option C: The funduscopy in retinal detachment shows detachment of fovea and macula, as shown below.

Option D: Fundoscopy changes in retinitis pigmentosa include perivascular retinal hyperpigmentation, narrow retinal arterioles, atrophy of retinal pigment epithelium, and disc pallor. It is shown below.

questions.text: During a disaster, rapidly classifying the injured on the basis of likelihood of their survival and need for intervention is called _____.
questions.solution:
Triage consists of rapidly classifying the injured in a disaster on the basis of severity of injury and likelihood of survival with prompt medical intervention. It is carried out at the site of disaster.

Tagging is the identification of patients in a disaster with tags stating their name, age, place of origin, triage category, diagnosis, and initial treatment.

Related Pearl: Triage Colour Coding

 Triage system consists of four colour codes:

Color code Priority Type of patients
Red High Need for immediate resuscitation or surgery in the next 6 hours or transfer (Eg. massive hemorrhage, tension pneumothorax)
Yellow Medium Possible resuscitation or surgery in next 24 hours (Eg. Isolated simple fracture)
Green Low Ambulatory patients or minor illness (Eg. Isolated abrasions, contusions, sprains)
Black Least  Dead or moribund patients (Eg. massive head injuries, 95% third degree burns)

questions.text: In rural areas, one ASHA worker is assigned to a population of ___ people.
questions.solution:
In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA.

An Accredited Social Health Activist (ASHA) does not procure ORS, contraceptives, IFA tablets, etc. from the CHC for her community.

An ASHA acts as a depot holder for these essential supplies, hence making them readily available to her community. These include Oral Rehydration Therapy (ORS), Iron Folic Acid tablets (IFA), chloroquine, Disposable Delivery Kits (DDK), Oral Pills & Condoms, etc.

General norm:

  • Must be a woman - married/divorced/widow (age group 25-45 years)
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000.

Relaxations in the general norm:

  • If no candidate is available with a qualification of 10th standard, the requirement can be relaxed to 8th standard.
  • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation.

Note: The States have been given the flexibility to relax the population norms as well as the educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions as far as her recruitment is concerned. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA is an Accredited Social Health Activist.

An ASHA must be a woman, a resident of the village, 25 to 45 years old and have a formal education till 10th standard preferably if they are in good numbers. This may be relaxed upto 8th standard only if no suitable person with this qualification is available. She is part of the primary health care at the village level.

National norm: In rural areas, a population of 1000 should have at least 1 ASHA, but in remote areas, one ASHA per habitation is the norm. In urban areas, 1 ASHA worker is assigned to a population of 1000-2500. This norm is also mandated by each state, differently, according to their requirements. 

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

questions.text: The students of a boarding school eat from the same canteen. One of the students developed abdominal pain, jaundice, and fever following which other students also presented with similar symptoms. Which of the following investigations should the Medical Officer of the area check for to reach a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is of a Hepatitis A outbreak that is spread via the fecal-oral route and the investigation of choice is IgM for Hepatitis A.

Hepatitis A:

Modes of transmission

  • Fecal-oral route: This is the major route of transmission. It can occur directly (handshake after toilet) or indirectly via contaminated food, water, or milk.
  • Parenteral route: This is very rare and occurs during the viral dissemination phase. It occurs during the prodromal phase and not when patients are symptomatic and admitted to the hospital. As a result, healthcare workers are not at increased risk.
  • Sexual transmission may occur in individuals practicing oro-anal methods (usually homosexual men). It however would not cause an outbreak.

Incubation period:

  • 10 to 50 days (usually 14-28 days). Isolation is not an effective measure to control outbreaks as the shedding of the virus is maximum during the early stages of illness when clinical illness may not have started and many patients are asymptomatic yet continue to shed the virus.

Clinical spectrum:

  • The onset of jaundice is preceded by gastrointestinal symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, anorexia, and mild fever.
  • Jaundice may appear within a few days of the prodromal period, but anicteric hepatitis is more common.
  • Hepatitis A resolves completely in 98 percent of cases but relapse of symptoms is noted in 3-20 percent of cases

Diagnosis:

  • Laboratory diagnosis of hepatitis A can be obtained by
    • Demonstration of HAV particles or specific viral antigens in the feces, bile, and blood.
    • Anti-HAV appears in the lgM fraction during the acute phase, peaking about 2 weeks after the elevation of liver enzymes. ELISA is the method of choice for measuring HAV antibodies.

Prevention and containment:

  • Control of reservoir: Use of 0.5 percent sodium hypochlorite has been strongly recommended as an effective disinfectant
  • Control of transmission: personal and community hygiene. Hand hygiene before food and after the toilet is highly recommended.
  • 1 mg/L of free residual chlorine can cause the destruction of the virus in 30 minutes at pH values of 8.5 or less. Hence adequate chlorination can be helpful.
  • Patients with chronic liver disease are at increased risk for fulminant hepatitis A and should be vaccinated. The use of the hepatitis A vaccine should be considered for pre-exposure(for travelers) and post-exposure(close contacts of affected individuals)prophylaxis.

questions.text: A 37-year-old woman presents with headaches for 6 months. She has been taking analgesics regularly. The headache recently increased in severity for 3 days but was reduced on stopping the analgesic. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of medication overuse headache.

Medication overuse headache is the headache occurring on ≥15 days/month due to overuse of headache medications for>3 months. It is also known as analgesic rebound headache, drug-induced headache, or medication-misuse headache. It usually resolves when the overuse is stopped.

Management: It includes the following steps:

  • Withdrawal of the overused medication
  • Treatment of withdrawal symptoms
  • Initiation of preventative therapy if required
  • Alternative symptomatic medication for future headaches

Other options:

Option B: Tension headache is a chronic headache syndrome characterized by bilateral, tight band-like discomfort. It can be episodic or chronic in nature. It is usually not associated with nausea, vomiting, etc.

Option C: Chronic migraine - Diagnostic criteria for migraine headache is as follows: Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 hours in patients with normal physical examination, no other reasonable cause for headache, and

At least 2 of the following features Plus at least 1 of the following features
Unilateral pain Nausea or vomiting
Throbbing pain Photophobia and phonophobia
Aggravation by movement  
Moderate or severe intensity  

Option D: Cluster headache is characterized by deep, excruciating, nonfluctuating pain which is usually retroorbital. The classical feature of this condition is its periodicity.  At least one of the daily attacks of pain recurs at almost the same hour every day.
Typically the patient has daily bouts of one or two attacks of relatively short-duration unilateral pain for 8–10 weeks a year. In between the clusters, there is a pain-free interval.

questions.text: A 46-year-old chronic alcoholic male presents to the OPD with fever, headache, shortness of breath, chest pain,  and productive cough for the last two days. On examination, there was bronchial breathing on the right side, increased vocal fremitus, increased vocal resonance, and a dull note on percussion. The patient's plain radiograph is shown below. Which is the most likely causative agent?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of lobar pneumonia. The above chest x-ray shows a bulging fissure sign. The likely causative organism is Klebsiella pneumoniae.

Klebsiella pneumonia is associated mostly with alcoholics and shows upper lobe involvement, cavitation, and pneumatocele (also seen in S. aureus). The patient presents with red currant-jelly sputum.

A bulging fissure sign is classically seen in Klebsiella pneumonia. It represents expansive lobar consolidation causing fissural bulging or displacement by copious amounts of inflammatory exudate within the affected parenchyma. Classically, it is associated with right upper lobe consolidation due to Klebsiella pneumonia.

Other diseases that manifest a bulging fissure include any space-occupying process in the lung, such as pulmonary hemorrhage, lung abscess, and tumor.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman comes to the physician because of generalized weakness for 6 months. She has also had frequent headaches, mild fever and severe jaw pain. She does not complain of any vision abnormality.  She appears pale. Laboratory tests show elevated levels of ESR. Peripheral smear shows normochromic anemia. What is the next best step in management?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a patient >50 years with fever, weakness, anemia, jaw claudication, and high ESR and CRP levels is suggestive of a diagnosis of giant cell arteritis.
The drug of choice is prednisone.

Giant cell arteritis (GCA), also known as temporal arteritis, is an inflammation of medium and large-sized vessels. It is more common in women and people aged >50 years.

The clinical features include headache associated with scalp pain and jaw claudication, fever, fatigue, malaise, and weight loss. Half of the patients have temporal artery abnormalities such as enlargement, tenderness, nodular swelling, and loss of pulse of the temporal artery, either unilateral or bilateral. Gentle pressure on the scalp may elicit focal or generalized tenderness. 

GCA is very commonly associated with polymyalgia rheumatica characterized by morning stiffness and pain around the shoulders and hip. Mononeuropathies or peripheral neuropathies can also be seen. A dreaded complication is ischemic optic neuropathy, which can lead to sudden blindness. Therefore treatment with oral steroids is given first and then a temporal artery biopsy is done for confirming the diagnosis. As the diagnosis may be done clinically, treatment is started immediately rather than delaying it after the biopsy.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman presents with fatigue. She had pallor on physical examination. Lab values are given below. Serum methyl malonyl CoA levels are normal. Which of the following should be administered as a therapy for this patient?

Hemoglobin - 9.8 g/dL

Platelets - 1,80,000/mm3

Leukocyte count - 7800/mm3

MCV - 106 fl
questions.solution:
This patient has megaloblastic anemia (high MCV). This could be due to various causes, commonly Vitamin B12 or folic acid deficiency. The presence of normal methylmalonyl Co-A favors folic acid deficiency. Thus folic acid has to be given as supplements.

Methylmalonyl-CoA mutase is a vitamin B12-dependent enzyme. The activity of methylmalonyl CoA mutase is greatly reduced in vitamin B12 deficiency, leading to an accumulation of methylmalonic acid and its excretion in urine and is also used to differentiate between megaloblastic anemia due to folate and vitamin B12 deficiency.

There are two vitamin B12-dependent enzymes:

  • Methionine synthase (Homocysteine methyltransferase): Catalyzes the conversion of homocysteine to methionine
  • Methylmalonyl CoA mutase: Methylmalonyl CoA, formed as an intermediate in the catabolism of valine, isoleucine and propionyl CoA is converted to succinyl CoA

Vitamin B12 acts as a cofactor of methionine synthase, an enzyme involved in the regeneration of tetrahydrofolate from methyl-tetrahydrofolate. Hence, in vitamin B12 deficiency methyl-tetrahydrofolate accumulates leading to functional folate deficiency known as the folate trap.

The conversion of 5,10-methylene-THF into 5-methyl-THF (methyltetrahydrofolate) is an irreversible process. The major source of tetrahydrofolate for tissues is 5-methyl-THF. The only way to make further use of 5-methyl-THF and to maintain the folate cycle is by the vitamin B12-dependent remethylation of homocysteine to methionine by the methionine synthase enzyme.

Decreased activity of methionine synthase in vitamin B12 deficiency results in the accumulation of methyltetrahydrofolate, which cannot be used, resulting in a folate trap. The folate cycle acts as the link between the functions of folate and vitamin B12, and deficiency of vitamin B12 can cause a functional deficiency of folate.

Causes of megaloblastic anaemia:-

  • Cobalamin deficiency/abnormalities of cobalamin metabolism: Nutritional, Malabsorption, absence of intrinsic factor, total/ partial gastrectomy.
  • Folate deficiency/ abnormalities of folate metabolism.
  • Therapy with antifolate drugs e.g., methotrexate.
  • Independent of cobalamin/folate deficiency:
    • Acute myeloid leukaemia, myelodysplasia.
    • Therapy with drugs interfering with the synthesis of DNA (e.g., cytosine arabinoside, hydroxyurea, 6-mercaptopurine).
    • Orotic aciduria (responds to uridine).

questions.text: A 50-year-old chronic alcoholic with a history of chronic liver disease presents to the emergency department with massive, sudden onset hematemesis. Which of the following is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a chronic alcoholic with sudden onset haematemesis is suggestive of esophageal variceal bleeding. 

The management of esophageal variceal bleeding involves:

  • Resuscitation with IV fluids, airway protection, and oxygen
  • Blood transfusion to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL
  • Antibiotic prophylaxis with ceftriaxone before endoscopy
  • An attempt at hemostasis with octreotide or terlipressin or vasopressin
  • Upper GI endoscopy within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation to confirm the source of the bleed
  • Endoscopic variceal band ligation or sclerotherapy
  • In case, of failure or rebleeding - TIPS

Nonselective beta-blockers like propranolol and nadolol are used in the prophylaxis of variceal bleeding.

questions.text: A 30-year-old lactating mother presents with pain in her left breast and fever. On examination of the affected side, there is localized erythema, warmth, point tenderness,fluctuation test is positive. There is mild axillary lymphadenopathy on the affected side and contralateral breast is normal.What is the management plan for this patient?

choices.text: Incision and Drainage after confirming with an ultrasound
Broad spectrum antibiotics only  after confirming with an ultrasound
Aspiration under USG guidance and antibiotics - Repeated aspiration if necessary
Punch biopsy under ultrasound guidance followed by a course of IV antibiotics

questions.solution:
The given case scenario points towards a diagnosis of breast abscess. The latest guidelines for the management of breast abscess specify that multiple aspirations under antibiotic cover should be attempted before an incision and drainage is done. This often allows resolution without the need for an incision scar and also allows the patient to continue breastfeeding.

Mastitis occurs due to the growth of staphylococcus or streptococcus due to breast milk stasis. This occurs secondary to blockage of lactiferous duct or due to incomplete emptying of breast milk or due to retracted nipple. Overgrowth of these bacteria results in the development of breast abscess.

It is commoner in new mothers at the beginning of lactation who are inexperienced with breastfeeding or during weaning when nipple trauma occurs due to the infant's growing teeth. 

Signs and symptoms of this condition involve:

  • Fever and malaise
  • Localized pain and tenderness 
  • Redness and swelling of the affected breast
  • Fluctuation test positive due to pus in the abscess. It is a late sign.

The initial treatment should involve providing pain relief with analgesics. The abscess should then be localized preferably under USG guidance and percutaneous aspiration carried out. The pus should be sent for microbiological examination to find the organism and antibiotic sensitivity. Repeated aspirations may be carried out under antibiotics cover if needed.

In some conditions mentioned below, the breast abscess may be unresponsive to repeated aspirations and antibiotic cover. In such cases, incision and drainage is performed. The conditions include:

  • Presence of thick pus
  • Bacteria resistant to antibiotics
  • If just superficial part has been aspirated in the presence of a multiloculated abscess
  • A non-healing breast abscess due to tuberculosis of breast or Inflammatory carcinoma of the breast, or an immunocompromised host.

questions.text: A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. He had an X-ray taken a few days ago, which is given below. Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with the X-ray showing nephrocalcinosis is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism.  

Nephrocalcinosis occurs in this condition due to hypercalcemia. It decreases renal concentrating ability, which may cause polyuria and polydipsia.

Clinical features of hyperparathyroidism:

  • Bones:
    • Pathological fractures
    • Subperiosteal bone resorption - 2nd and 3rd digits, most common in radial aspect
    • Salt and pepper skull
    • Osteitis fibrosa cystica or VonReckling Hausen’s disease
  • Stones
    • Multiple and recurrent renal stones - most common
    • Nephrocalcinosis
  • Abdominal groans - colicky due to pancreatitis
  • Psychiatric overtones - raised PTH causing CNS depression and psychiatric symptoms
  • Band keratopathy
  • Features of hypercalcemia - 
    • Vomiting
    • Confusion
    • ECG changes: increased PR interval, shortened QT interval

 The image given below shows salt and pepper skull seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Investigations done in primary hyperparathyroidism:

  • Ultrasonography of the neck is a safe and widely used technique for the localization of abnormal parathyroid glands.  
  • Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is also a widely used technique. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas. This radionuclide is concentrated in the thyroid and parathyroid tissue but usually washes out of normal thyroid tissue in under an hour. It persists in abnormal parathyroid tissue.  
  • Dual-energy radiographic absorptiometry is a useful tool to demonstrate skeletal involvement in primary hyperparathyroidism.

The image given below shows a radiolabeled Sestamibi scan.

questions.text: An elderly lady presents to the trauma care centre following a motor vehicle collision. She complains of chest pain and abdominal pain. On examination, breath sounds are decreased on the right side. X ray chest revealed the following finding. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this patient?

choices.text: Most accurate evaluation of this condition is by VATS
Operative repair is indicated in all cases
In case of penetrating injury, repair can be done via thoracic incision
The defect must be closed with polypropylene sutures

questions.solution:
The given clinical history and X-ray image showing obliteration of the diaphragmatic outline are suggestive of traumatic diaphragmatic injury in this patient. Penetrating diaphragmatic injury must be repaired via the abdomen and not the thorax, to rule out penetrating hollow viscus injury. 

Patients with diaphragmatic injury are generally asymptomatic. Chest X ray after the insertion of a nasogastric tube may help in identifying the herniation of the stomach in the thoracic cavity. However, the most accurate evaluation is by video assisted thoracoscopy (VATS) or laparoscopy. Abdominal contents may get herniated into the chest and get strangulated later. This is associated with high mortality. Hence, operative repair is indicated in all patients. The defect is closed with running 1-0 polypropylene suture.

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents to the OG clinic with complaints of lower abdominal pain and mild bleeding per vaginum for 2 days at 12 weeks of gestation.  She also complains of excessive vomiting for one week. USG was done and it is given below.  What is the probable diagnosis____
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture along with the image is suggestive of complete mole.  The USG image shows the characteristic “snowstorm” appearance seen in complete mole.

It is due to an echogenic uterine mass that has numerous anechoic cystic spaces.

Notably, a fetus and amnionic sac are absent. 

Snowstorms in radiology:

  • Complete hydatiform mole (ultrasound)
  • Extracapsular breast implant rupture (ultrasound)
  • Thyroid pulmonary metastases (chest radiograph)

questions.text: A primigravid woman at 34 weeks of gestation was taken for emergency cesarean section after presenting with premature rupture of membranes and severe abdominal pain. Laparotomy revealed patches of dark port wine color over the uterus. In which of the following conditions can this complication be expected?
questions.solution:
The laparotomy finding is suggestive of uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus, and this complication can be expected in abruptio placenta.

Abruptio placenta is the partial/total placental separation from its implantation site before delivery. The bleeding may be:

  • Revealed (blood dissects downwards between membranes and uterine wall to escape through the cervix) or
  • Concealed (blood accumulates between detached placenta and uterus)

Risk factors for abruptio placenta include prior abruption history, preterm premature rupture of membranes, and pregnancy-associated hypertension. Patients often present with sudden onset abdominal pain, vaginal bleeding, uterine tenderness, and frequent contractions.

Uteroplacental apoplexy/Couvelaire uterus is a complication seen in severe types of concealed abruptio placentae. There is massive intravasation of blood into the uterine musculature, potentially extending up to the serous coat. It is only diagnosed on laparotomy, where a port-wine-colored uterus (diffuse or patchy) is seen. Though the uterus may lose its contractility, increasing the risk of bleeding, it rarely causes uterine atony. Hence, Couvelaire uterus does not require hysterectomy until uterine atony occurs.

Other complications of abruptio placenta include: 

  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation
  • Hypovolemic shock due to torrential bleeding
  • Acute kidney injury

Abruptio placenta is mostly managed by immediate delivery and management of complications such as shock with adequate blood products.

Other options: 

Option A: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta is implanted in the lower uterine segment over or very near to the cervical os. Vaginal bleeding is usually painless in this condition.

Option B: Preeclampsia is a multisystem disorder that occurs after 20 weeks due to the new onset of hypertension and proteinuria. Patients complain of headaches, epigastric pain, decreased urine output, and blurring of vision.

Option D: Uterine inversion is a complication that occurs in the third stage of labor. The uterus is partially/completely turned inside out due to various factors, such as fundally implanted placenta, uterine atony, placenta accrete syndrome, and cord traction before the placenta is separated. It produces acute lower abdominal pain with a bearing down sensation and leads to massive bleeding.

questions.text: A patient presents with an endometrial thickness of 14mm with an adnexal mass. She has a history of complex endometrial hyperplasia with the presence of atypical cells. Which of the following is likely the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with endometrial hyperplasia and an adnexal mass likely has endometrial cancer with metastasis to the ovaries.

For those who undergo TVUS (transvaginal USG) and have an EEC (endometrial echo complex) >4 mm, localized thickening, or an indistinct or nonvisible EEC, endometrial sampling is a reasonable next step.

Investigations for endometrial carcinoma include:

  • Endometrial aspiration biopsy is the first investigation for abnormal uterine bleeding, especially in females >35 years.
  • Dilatation and fractional curettage was the best diagnosis method, but now it is not used.
  • Hysteroscopy and biopsy: The investigation of choice for endometrial cancer.
  • Transvaginal USG is used as an adjunct to endometrial biopsy.
  • A Pap smear is not reliable to diagnose endometrial carcinoma. It is more useful as a screening tool rather than a diagnostic tool.

If symptoms of postmenopausal bleeding persist, imaging of the endometrial cavity should be performed with one or a combination of the following: TVUS, contrast sonography, or hysteroscopy.

Note: Surgical staging is the gold standard investigation for staging endometrial carcinoma.

Other options:

Option A: Struma ovarii is a type of highly specialized teratoma that contains only thyroid tissue. If it is functioning, it may lead to hyperthyroidism.

Option C: Polycystic ovarian disease is a disease characterized by menstrual abnormalities and hyperandrogenism in women of reproductive age. This condition has been linked to risk factors such as obesity and insulin resistance. Clinically these patients present with infertility and features of hyperandrogenism such as hirsutism and acne. On ultrasound, these patients have larger ovaries with an increased number of follicles. Multiple follicles that are peripherally located in the ovary can be seen on ultrasound. This is also called the string of pearls sign.

Option D: Immature teratomas such as solid teratomas of the ovary are solid and trabeculated. They also contain cartilage, bone, hair, and sebaceous material. There is no structural order. They are generally malignant. Grossly, they have a smooth external surface and are solid on sectioning. There may be areas of necrosis or hemorrhage.

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement about cephalhematoma?

choices.text: It is usually found immediately after birth
It usually gets absorbed within 2-4 days
It is usually located on the presenting part of the head

questions.solution:
The true statement about cephalhematoma is that it may cause neonatal jaundice.

Cephalhematoma is a well-defined swelling that is contained within suture lines and does not cross them. It is not present at the time of birth and usually develops after a few hours/one day. This swelling is usually filled with blood. Hence, the resulting hemolysis leads to the development of jaundice with hyperbilirubinemia in the neonate. Some babies may require phototherapy in severe cases. It resolves within 2 weeks to a few months.

Caput succedaneum is an ill-defined swelling over the scalp that is caused by excessive pressure to the neonatal head by the cervix and pelvic walls during vaginal delivery. It presents as a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It is present at the time of delivery. It does not require any treatment and disappears within 1 week of life. Scalp ecchymoses are a feature of this condition.

Sub-galeal hemorrhage- It is an accumulation of blood underneath the aponeurosis of the scalp (galea aponeurotica). This is also a diffuse swelling and is not limited by suture lines. It usually occurs due to rupture of emissary veins and is associated with vacuum-assisted delivery. A timely diagnosis is essential to prevent hypovolemic shock and death of the neonate.

Related Pearl: Caput succedaneum and Cephalohematoma

Time of appearance  Immediately after birth Several hours after birth
Cause Prolonged labor, causing venous stasis and edema  Instrumental delivery, causes rupture of emissary veins in skull
Extent of movement Both hemispheres; crosses the suture line Individual bones; do not cross the suture lines
Period of absorption 2-4 days 2 weeks to 3 months
Treatment None

Supportive.

questions.text: A carpenter presents with bilateral knee pain and fluctuating swelling in the front of the knee. There is inflammation and tenderness over his knee. MRI of knee is given. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The fluctuating swelling in the front of the knee as well as the image, both suggest Housemaid Bursitis. 

Housemaid's knee is nothing but prepatellar bursitis and is seen in the lower half of patella and upper half of ligamentum patella. Suprapatellar bursa always communicates with the knee joint.

Lower limb major bursitis:

  • Prepatellar Bursitis (Housemaid's Knee)
  • Infrapatellar bursitis (Clergyman's knee) (option C)
  • Trochanteric Bursitis (Above hip abductor) 
    The image shows a sagittal section through the left knee joint (lateral aspect) with bursae.

Other options:

Option A: Olecranon bursitis, also known as draughtsman's elbow (or student's elbow or miner's elbow). Olecranon bursitis is a chronic inflammation of the olecranon bursa, as a result of repetitive minor injuries. It is seen in people who tend to keep their elbow rubbed against the desk. The constant friction against the olecranon bursa can lead to the development of bursitis.

Option D: Gout is characterized by an inflammatory reaction that results in the formation of gouty tophi and arthropathy when monosodium urate (MSU) crystals are deposited in the soft tissue and joints. A definitive diagnosis necessitates the microscopic identification of MSU crystals through joint fluid aspiration.

questions.text:
Match the following:
1 - Kleptomania A - Intense desire to drink alcoholic drinks
2 - Pyromania B - Intense desire to mutilate
3 - Mutilomania C - Intense desire to steal items of trivial value
4 - Dipsomania D - Intense desire to burn things
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1-C, 2-D, 3-B, 4-A

Impulse control disorders are characterized by the repeated failure to resist an impulse, drive, or urge to perform an act that is rewarding to the person, at least in the short-term, despite consequences such as long-term harm either to the individual or to others; marked distress about the behavior pattern; or significant impairment in personal, family, social, educational, occupational, or other important areas of functioning.

It includes

  1. Pyromania
  2. Kleptomania 
  3. Compulsive sexual behavior disorder
  4. Intermittent explosive disorder

Kleptomania is the repeated failure to resist impulses to steal objects that are of no value to the person. The individual can usually afford the object or does not need it, but it is the act of stealing itself that is the goal. The stolen objects are usually given away, returned, or kept hidden. The act is not planned and is carried out alone.

Pyromania is the deliberate setting of fires on more than one occasion. 

Pyromania is significantly associated with the following:

  • Substance abuse disorder (especially alcoholism).
  • Affective disorders (depression or bipolar)
  • Other impulse control disorders, such as kleptomania in female firesetters.
  • Personality disturbances, such as borderline personality disorders.
  • Attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder and learning disabilities in childhood pyromania.

Mutilomania is an irresistible impulse to mutilate animals.

Dipsomania is an irresistible impulse to drink alcohol at periodic intervals.

questions.text: A 20-year-old primi in her second trimester of pregnancy is posted for the open appendectomy. The ideal anesthetic technique for this surgery is _______
questions.solution:
Spinal anesthesia is preferred over other techniques for the appendectomy in the second trimester. Total anesthetic drug exposure is least with spinal anesthesia over others.

General anesthesia is associated with a greater risk of:

  • Pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents
  • Difficult or failed intubation
  • Drug exposure to the fetus

Epidural anesthesia has the risk of

  • Accidental intravascular injection
  • Accidental intrathecal injection

In general, spinal anesthesia is appropriate for open appendectomies and general anesthesia for laparoscopic appendectomies.

Related Pearl: Regional Anesthesia in Obstetrics

  • Pregnant patients display enhanced sensitivity to LA during regional anesthesia because of hormonal factors and engorgement of epidural venous plexus resulting in decreased epidural space and subarachnoid space (CSF volume).This enhances the cephalad spread of LA solution during spinal and epidural anesthesia.
  • Lower doses of LA agents and pain relief drugs are used because of altered pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics during parturition as a result of hormonal and cardiovascular effects.
  • Lignocaine is less protein bound and nerves are more sensitive to LA agents.
  • NOT a cause of decreased anesthetic requirement during pregnancy Increased lumbar lordosis.
  • The level of the block under spinal anesthesia is desirable upto T4.
  • Lumbar epidural - The most preferred technique for painless labor.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the image below.
questions.solution:
The image shows Beau’s lines.

They are transverse grooves which are present on the nail and may be full or partial thickness through the nail. Transverse grooves may occur due to trauma, inflammation or neurological event, reflecting an acute systemic event (like MI, measles, mumps or pneumonia).

Option b:  Mees' lines

Option c: Lindsay Nail

questions.text: A patient complains of neck stiffness and severe headache. The CT image shown below is suggestive of which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The clinical manifestations of neck stiffness and severe headache with CT revealing blood in the basal cistern points out to the diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

 

 

Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is the bleeding into the subarachnoid space, which is the area between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater surrounding the brain. The diagnosis is suspected when a hyperattenuating material is seen filling the subarachnoid space. Most commonly this is apparent around the circle of Willis, on account of the majority of berry aneurysms occurring in this region, or in the Sylvian fissure.

Young males with a history of spontaneous sudden onset severe headache with seizures should raise suspicion for subarachnoid hemorrhage (aneurysmal). The most common cause of SAH is head trauma and the second common cause is rupture of a saccular aneurysm.

Symptoms include:

  • Severe headache (thunderclap headache)
  • Rapid onset vomiting
  • Confusion or a lowered level of consciousness
  • Seizures
  • Neck stiffness or neck pain

questions.text: Which one of the following has maximum ionisation potential?
questions.solution:
Alpha particle is similar to helium with two protons and two neutron has maximum ionising potential but least penetrating ability and penetrates only superficial tissues to extent of 1 mm.

Gamma rays have the maximum tissue penetrating ability.

Related Pearl: Ionising and penetrating ability of radiation

  • Penetration power: Gamma rays > X-rays > Beta particle > Alpha particle (helium ion)
  • Ionising or tissue damaging ability: Alpha particle (helium ion) > Beta particle > X-ray > Gamma ray
  • Alpha waves have the highest molecular mass
